newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries open higher on shortened trading day.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries open higher on shortened trading day.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices opened higher on Friday in what will be a shortened trading session ahead of the three-day Memorial Day holiday weekend.
Trading is expected to be quiet, participants said.

"This could be one of the more quiet days thus far in 1997," said Kevin Flanagan, first vice president and money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "There's no data of consequence. And there really aren't any looming on the horizon. Next week you get April durables and the Chicago PMI and the (two- and five-year Treasury note) auctions."
"We're really a couple of weeks away from getting fresh economic statistics for May," Flanagan said. "And that's what we neeed as a catalyst to move us out of this training range.
"With the two o'clock close and the unofficial start of summer (on Memorial Day), it's going to be a very, very quiet session," he said.
At the open, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was up 6/32 to 95-20/32, yielding 6.98 percent, versus 6.99 percent at Thursday's close.
At the shorter end of the yield curve, the two-year Treasury note was up 1/32 to 100-9/32, yielding 6.23 percent.
Kim Rupert, senior economist at MMS International, said trading is likely to be "fairly lackluster and quiet heading into the long weekend.
"After this week's activity, everybody is wanting to go home, close out a position and leave," she said.

Rupert said the market is maintaining a bit of a bid with the dollar relatively stable. But she said she did not anticipate significant price movements and the market, if anything, would be technically driven.
Fed Governor Laurence Meyer is scheduled to speak in the afternoon, she noted, but is unlikely to move the market.
Noting the firming trend in overseas trade earlier, Rupert cited a "fairly large buyer of two-year notes in Japan and some interest in the middle of the yield curve during the European session."
Flanagan also saw "a little bit of buying overseas, though nothing dramatic."
Looking ahead, Rupert said the Treasury's two- and five-year note auctions would probably highlight the Treasury market's schedule next week.
The Treasury will sell $16.5 billion in two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.0 billion in five-year notes on Thursday.

"I don't foresee a real problem with either of the auctions," Rupert said. "We will probably back up a little before then. But I think the two-year auction will go off fairly well in the 6.25 (percent yield) area."
In early trade, 10-year notes traded at 99-9/32, up 6/32, to yield 6.73 percent. Five-year notes traded at 100-8/32, up 3/32, to yield 6.56 percent.

Three-month bill rates were down three basis points to 5.01 percent. Six-month rates were down one basis point to 5.22 percent. Year bill rates were down one basis point to 5.52 percent. ((--North American Treasury Desk 212 859 1679))
